moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3
1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3 h6 13. Bh4 Bb7 14. Nd2 cxd4 15. exd4 e5 16. Bf5
comment:
Its always very
tempting to set up raking Bishops like this. Here Black is coerced into
playing his Rook to an awkward square to avoid White breaching the Black
Kingside defences by Bxd7 followed by Bxf6.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3 h6 13. Bh4 Bb7 14. Nd2 cxd4 15. exd4 e5 16. Bf5 Rc7 17. dxe5 dxe5 18. Rad1 Qa8 19. f3 Re8 20. Rfe1 g6 21. Bb1 Re6 22. Qe3
comment: Hitting the h6 pawn, but mainly to get out of the way of the b pawn.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3 h6 13. Bh4 Bb7 14. Nd2 cxd4 15. exd4 e5 16. Bf5 Rc7 17. dxe5 dxe5 18. Rad1 Qa8 19. f3 Re8 20. Rfe1 g6 21. Bb1 Re6 22. Qe3 Qf8 23. b4 a5 24. Qb3 axb4 25. axb4 Kg7 26. Bf2
comment:
The Bishop has done its job on g5 and h4. From f2
it attacks the weak Black pawn onb6, ensuring that Black will need to keep a
protective eye on it constantly. If Black covers the weakness by moving the
pawn forward, he allows a vaery big passed pawn on c5.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3 h6 13. Bh4 Bb7 14. Nd2 cxd4 15. exd4 e5 16. Bf5 Rc7 17. dxe5 dxe5 18. Rad1 Qa8 19. f3 Re8 20. Rfe1 g6 21. Bb1 Re6 22. Qe3 Qf8 23. b4 a5 24. Qb3 axb4 25. axb4 Kg7 26. Bf2 Qe7 27. Be3 Ne8 28. Bd3
comment:
Overprotecting the c pawn to allow the Queen freedom of movement. Ne4 was the
main alternative I considered.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3 h6 13. Bh4 Bb7 14. Nd2 cxd4 15. exd4 e5 16. Bf5 Rc7 17. dxe5 dxe5 18. Rad1 Qa8 19. f3 Re8 20. Rfe1 g6 21. Bb1 Re6 22. Qe3 Qf8 23. b4 a5 24. Qb3 axb4 25. axb4 Kg7 26. Bf2 Qe7 27. Be3 Ne8 28. Bd3 Nd6 29. Qa3 Qh4 30. Ra1 Re8 31. Bf2 Qg5 32. Qb2
comment:
Pinning the e pawn and preparing to embarrass the Black
Queen. Also, there is a possible swap of Rooks coming up on the a file, and
White wants to initiate it so as to keep a Rook on e1. So the White Queen
comes off the a file.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3 h6 13. Bh4 Bb7 14. Nd2 cxd4 15. exd4 e5 16. Bf5 Rc7 17. dxe5 dxe5 18. Rad1 Qa8 19. f3 Re8 20. Rfe1 g6 21. Bb1 Re6 22. Qe3 Qf8 23. b4 a5 24. Qb3 axb4 25. axb4 Kg7 26. Bf2 Qe7 27. Be3 Ne8 28. Bd3 Nd6 29. Qa3 Qh4 30. Ra1 Re8 31. Bf2 Qg5 32. Qb2 Ra8 33. Rxa8 Bxa8 34. Bg3
comment:
I like this one, the principle idea behind
White's 32nd. The idea is to force Black to defend his e pawn with f6, thereby
blocking in his own Queen, which White now keeps under constant threat.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3 h6 13. Bh4 Bb7 14. Nd2 cxd4 15. exd4 e5 16. Bf5 Rc7 17. dxe5 dxe5 18. Rad1 Qa8 19. f3 Re8 20. Rfe1 g6 21. Bb1 Re6 22. Qe3 Qf8 23. b4 a5 24. Qb3 axb4 25. axb4 Kg7 26. Bf2 Qe7 27. Be3 Ne8 28. Bd3 Nd6 29. Qa3 Qh4 30. Ra1 Re8 31. Bf2 Qg5 32. Qb2 Ra8 33. Rxa8 Bxa8 34. Bg3 f6 35. Bf2
comment: Back to harassing the pawn on b6.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3 h6 13. Bh4 Bb7 14. Nd2 cxd4 15. exd4 e5 16. Bf5 Rc7 17. dxe5 dxe5 18. Rad1 Qa8 19. f3 Re8 20. Rfe1 g6 21. Bb1 Re6 22. Qe3 Qf8 23. b4 a5 24. Qb3 axb4 25. axb4 Kg7 26. Bf2 Qe7 27. Be3 Ne8 28. Bd3 Nd6 29. Qa3 Qh4 30. Ra1 Re8 31. Bf2 Qg5 32. Qb2 Ra8 33. Rxa8 Bxa8 34. Bg3 f6 35. Bf2 Nf5 36. Ne4 Bxe4
comment: And White reaps the first reward of his strategy; the two Bishops.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3 h6 13. Bh4 Bb7 14. Nd2 cxd4 15. exd4 e5 16. Bf5 Rc7 17. dxe5 dxe5 18. Rad1 Qa8 19. f3 Re8 20. Rfe1 g6 21. Bb1 Re6 22. Qe3 Qf8 23. b4 a5 24. Qb3 axb4 25. axb4 Kg7 26. Bf2 Qe7 27. Be3 Ne8 28. Bd3 Nd6 29. Qa3 Qh4 30. Ra1 Re8 31. Bf2 Qg5 32. Qb2 Ra8 33. Rxa8 Bxa8 34. Bg3 f6 35. Bf2 Nf5 36. Ne4 Bxe4 37. Rxe4 h5
comment: Creating a retreat for the Queen.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3 h6 13. Bh4 Bb7 14. Nd2 cxd4 15. exd4 e5 16. Bf5 Rc7 17. dxe5 dxe5 18. Rad1 Qa8 19. f3 Re8 20. Rfe1 g6 21. Bb1 Re6 22. Qe3 Qf8 23. b4 a5 24. Qb3 axb4 25. axb4 Kg7 26. Bf2 Qe7 27. Be3 Ne8 28. Bd3 Nd6 29. Qa3 Qh4 30. Ra1 Re8 31. Bf2 Qg5 32. Qb2 Ra8 33. Rxa8 Bxa8 34. Bg3 f6 35. Bf2 Nf5 36. Ne4 Bxe4 37. Rxe4 h5 38. Qc2
comment:
White wants to bring the Rook down from e4, where it blocks the diagonal of
the Bishop on d3, and is also exposed to attack. But on e4 the Rook keeps an
important eye on h4, preventing the Knight from going there. The problem is
that Black then has a strong Knight sac on f3 which comes very close to
equalising for Black, since White probably has to whip it off for his
black-squared Bishop to prevent it.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3 h6 13. Bh4 Bb7 14. Nd2 cxd4 15. exd4 e5 16. Bf5 Rc7 17. dxe5 dxe5 18. Rad1 Qa8 19. f3 Re8 20. Rfe1 g6 21. Bb1 Re6 22. Qe3 Qf8 23. b4 a5 24. Qb3 axb4 25. axb4 Kg7 26. Bf2 Qe7 27. Be3 Ne8 28. Bd3 Nd6 29. Qa3 Qh4 30. Ra1 Re8 31. Bf2 Qg5 32. Qb2 Ra8 33. Rxa8 Bxa8 34. Bg3 f6 35. Bf2 Nf5 36. Ne4 Bxe4 37. Rxe4 h5 38. Qc2 Ra7 39. Qd1 Nd6 40. Re2 Nf5 41. Kh1
comment:
White is still worried about N-h4xf3 ideas. This is the first
prophylactic step to refutating the plan. But White must keep a close eye on
back rank tactics from Black now. For example, Black can play Ra1 in some
lines to rescue his Queen.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3 h6 13. Bh4 Bb7 14. Nd2 cxd4 15. exd4 e5 16. Bf5 Rc7 17. dxe5 dxe5 18. Rad1 Qa8 19. f3 Re8 20. Rfe1 g6 21. Bb1 Re6 22. Qe3 Qf8 23. b4 a5 24. Qb3 axb4 25. axb4 Kg7 26. Bf2 Qe7 27. Be3 Ne8 28. Bd3 Nd6 29. Qa3 Qh4 30. Ra1 Re8 31. Bf2 Qg5 32. Qb2 Ra8 33. Rxa8 Bxa8 34. Bg3 f6 35. Bf2 Nf5 36. Ne4 Bxe4 37. Rxe4 h5 38. Qc2 Ra7 39. Qd1 Nd6 40. Re2 Nf5 41. Kh1 Rc7 42. g3 h4 43. g4 h3
comment: Saving the Queen, and the Knight, by tactical means.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3 h6 13. Bh4 Bb7 14. Nd2 cxd4 15. exd4 e5 16. Bf5 Rc7 17. dxe5 dxe5 18. Rad1 Qa8 19. f3 Re8 20. Rfe1 g6 21. Bb1 Re6 22. Qe3 Qf8 23. b4 a5 24. Qb3 axb4 25. axb4 Kg7 26. Bf2 Qe7 27. Be3 Ne8 28. Bd3 Nd6 29. Qa3 Qh4 30. Ra1 Re8 31. Bf2 Qg5 32. Qb2 Ra8 33. Rxa8 Bxa8 34. Bg3 f6 35. Bf2 Nf5 36. Ne4 Bxe4 37. Rxe4 h5 38. Qc2 Ra7 39. Qd1 Nd6 40. Re2 Nf5 41. Kh1 Rc7 42. g3 h4 43. g4 h3 44. Be4 Nf8
comment:
A good all
move. Black frees his Rook from defending the Knight on d7. More importantly,
if this Knight  can reach f4 it blocks the black diagonal leading to the Queen
on g5.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3 h6 13. Bh4 Bb7 14. Nd2 cxd4 15. exd4 e5 16. Qb2 Ra8 33. Rxa8 Bxa8 34. Bg3 f6 35. Bf2 Nf5 36. Ne4 Bxe4 37. Rxe4 h5 38. Qc2 Ra7 39. Qd1 Nd6 40. Re2 Nf5 41. Kh1 Rc7 42. g3 h4 43. g4 h3 44. Be4 Nf8 45. Bd5 Nd7 46. Qe1
comment: Strengthening White's grip on the vital e1-h4 diagonal. Black is now lost.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qc2 O-O 5. a3 Bxc3+ 6. Qxc3 b6 7. Bg5 Ba6 8. e3 d6 9. Bd3 Nbd7 10. Nf3 c5 11. O-O Rc8 12. Qb3 h6 13. Bh4 Bb7 14. Nd2 cxd4 15. exd4 e5 16. comment: And Black resigned here. He is lost with best play, for example if ..
